title: Union Council Nikah Nama & NADRA MRC Registration Guide
legal_basis: Muslim Family Laws Ordinance 1961 (Section 5 mandatory registration) + provincial laws (e.g., Punjab Child Marriage Restraint Ordinance 2026)

whats_this.heading: Nikah Nama & MRC Wizard
whats_this.description: All Muslim marriages in Pakistan must be registered at the Union Council (or equivalent) within days/weeks of Nikah. After UC registration, a computerized Marriage Registration Certificate (MRC) is issued via NADRA. This wizard helps you navigate the 2026 legal requirements, fees, and digital registration options.
quick_instructions: Select your marriage case details (Local, Foreign spouse, or Polygamy)
Determine your location to find the relevant Union Council
Generate a personalized document checklist and timeline
Explore digital registration via Pak ID app in pilot districts
Validate your certificate details before official use
whats_this.disclaimer: This is general guidance based on 2026 regulations. Laws and procedures can vary by province and specific circumstances. Always verify with your local Union Council or NADRA center.

case_type.title: Marriage Case Details
case_type.description: Your requirements depend on the nature of the marriage and the citizenship of the parties.

types.title: Foreign Spouse
types.description: One party is a foreign national

case_type.eligibility_note: Critical: As of 2026, Punjab requires 18 years minimum for BOTH bride and groom. Other provinces may vary (some 16 for females), but 18 is the standard for NADRA registration.

location.title: Location Information
location.description: Marriage registration is typically done at the Union Council of the area where the Nikah took place or where the bride resides.

provinces.name: Punjab
provinces.pilot_note: Digital registration via Pak ID app is widely available in many Punjab UCs.

documents_checklist.description: 2 recent photos of bride & groom (white background)

documents_checklist.label: Embassy NOC
documents_checklist.description: For foreign spouses, NOC from their respective embassy

items.label: Groom's name and CNIC match exactly
Bride's name and CNIC match exactly
Registration date is within official limits
Official seal and QR code are present

tips: Always use licensed Nikah Khawan (registered with UC).
Get 3–4 copies of signed Nikah Nama immediately after ceremony.
Check Pak ID app for supported digital registration UCs.
pitfalls: Assuming old age rules apply in Punjab (must be 18+ for both now).
Marriage below legal age is voidable/criminal; UC will refuse registration.
Ignoring Iddat period makes registration invalid.

tips: Registration is usually done where the Nikah took place. If the parties reside elsewhere, supplementary docs may be needed.
Digital registration via Pak ID app is widely available in many Punjab pilot UCs.
Register within 15–30 days to avoid late fees/penalties.
In pilot districts like Lahore/Faisalabad, use Pak ID app for biometric registration.
pitfalls: Don't pay extra to 'agents' — stick to official UC/NADRA fees.
Delaying registration leads to complications in FRC/Passport updates later.

tips: Keep original Nikah Nama safe; never submit original to UC indefinitely.
For abroad/proxy marriages: Register at Pakistan Mission first → MOFA attestation.
pitfalls: Strict Polygamy Advisory: Arbitration Council permission is MANDATORY under Section 6 MFLO.
Incomplete docs (e.g. missing witness CNIC) will cause rejection.
Not getting Arbitration permission in polygamy is a criminal offense.

tips: Verify UC Secretary Presence: Usually available morning only (Nikah Registrars/Secretaries).
E-Khidmat Markaz in Punjab can also facilitate MRC applications.
Confirmed pilot districts for digital MRC: Lahore, Faisalabad, Chakwal, Jhelum.
pitfalls: UC offices may have irregular timings; call first if possible.

tips: Scan the QR code on your MRC to verify authenticity on the spot.
Get MRC attested by MOFA if applying for a foreign visa.
pitfalls: Errors in CNIC digits on MRC will prevent FRC updates.
